title: Glad You Asked: Survivor Benefits Scams
summary:
After the loss of a Veteran, families may receive suspicious calls, texts, or emails about VA benefits.

Scammers often target survivors during this difficult time. Deputy Secretary, Paul R. Lawrence, Ph.D. shares practical tips to help survivors protect themselves: 

• Contact VA directly at 1-800-827-1000 with any questions 
• Safeguard DD214s and military records 
• Create and use a VA.gov account 
• Avoid clicking on links in texts or emails 
• Do not share personal information 
• Review documents carefully

Be vigilant, especially in times of bereavement, and know that VA is here to support you.

title: Caregiver Resources in 2 (Caregiver Support Teams)
summary:
One of the best resources available to Caregivers are the Caregiver Support Program teams. They have expertise in caregiving, and most importantly, are caring professionals. And there's a team at every VA. They're here for you, here to listen and understand your unique needs as a caregiver. 

The team is knowledgeable about the various resources available to you as a caregiver, both at VA and in the community, and they will help match you with the right services and support. They can also help you connect with other caregivers and provide you with valuable information to help you care for the Veteran and yourself. Your caregiver support team can provide one-on-one support to you. They're available to listen to you and your needs. They can provide coaching both around the skills you need to care for the changing needs of the veteran you care for, or coaching to help you develop goals related to your own health. They can enroll you in a support group where you can connect with other caregivers. They can even connect you with a peer support mentor, another caregiver who is walking a similar journey. It can help you enhance your coping skills, help you manage the normal emotions that come along with caregiving, and decrease the stress you may be feeling as a caregiver. By engaging in skills training or coaching you can increase your confidence as you learn new tools to help you manage the day to day care needs. 

By connecting with other caregivers, you can decrease any sense of isolation you may be feeling and increase your feelings of connectedness. Caregiver Support Teams draw upon your strengths as a person and as a caregiver and help you create a plan with the focus on caring for you. The best thing to do is to go to https://www.caregiver.va.gov and click on find your local Caregiver Support Coordinator. To find your team, visit caregiver.va.gov and click on find your local Caregiver Support Coordinator.

title: Assessment of CSU’s Graduation Initiative 2025
summary: This report focuses on the California State University’s (CSU’s) Graduation Initiative 2025 (GI 2025). This initiative aimed to increase graduation rates and close gaps in graduation rates among particular student groups by 2025. In the report, we provide background on GI 2025, then discuss associated funding and activities. Next, we analyze the outcomes and assess the benefits and drawbacks of GI 2025. Lastly, we make recommendations for the Legislature to consider as it contemplates its involvement in CSU’s next graduation initiative.

title: Assessment of the Strong Workforce Program
summary: This report focuses on the Strong Workforce Program, which the state created to increase the availability and quality of career technical education at the California Community Colleges. We provide background on the program, assess its implementation and outcomes, and raise a few issues to consider relating to coordination of workforce development programs more broadly.

title: Updating California’s School Funding Formula: Assessing Alternatives and Trade-Offs

While student outcomes have improved, schools still face fiscal and academic challenges. This report examines how tweaks to the funding system could affect state spending and district allocations, highlighting the trade-offs involved.

source: Publication Archive - Public Policy Institute of California
title: Policy Brief: Updating California’s School Funding Formula
summary: We model the state’s school funding system and consider several distinct changes, ranging in cost from $1.5 to $3.8 billion, that could address ongoing challenges. Each change leads to different funding levels across districts and student groups.

title: Healthy Teaching Kitchen: Lentil Tacos
summary:
The VA Healthy Teaching Kitchen presents a quick, plant-based, budget-friendly lunch or dinner option, featuring ingredients commonly found in food pantries.

Lentil Tacos Prep: 10 minutes | Cook: 45 minutes | Total: 55 minutes | Yield: 4 servings | Serving Size: 2 tacos without optional toppings

Ingredients:
1 tablespoon canola or olive oil1 (1-ounce) packet taco seasoning
2 cups (16 ounces) low-sodium vegetable broth
1 (8-ounce) can no-salt-added tomato sauce
1 (4-ounce) can diced green chiles
3/4 cup uncooked green or brown lentils, picked through and rinsed
8 (5 to 6-inch) corn tortillasOptional toppings: Cheese, bell peppers, onion, cilantro, lettuce

Directions:
1. Add the oil and taco seasoning to a medium saucepan.  Stir together to make a paste.
2. Place the pot over medium heat and cook until fragrant, about 3-5 minutes.
3. Add the broth, tomato sauce, green chiles, and lentils.  Stir to combine, scraping up any browned bits.
4. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce the heat to maintain a simmer.
5. Cover with a lid and cook until the lentils are tender, about 30-40 minutes.  If any liquid is left at the end of cooking, remove the lid and simmer to evaporate.
6. Divide the lentil mixture between the tortillas (~1/3 cup each) and serve warm, adding toppings as desired.

Nutrition Facts Per Serving: Calories: 280 | Total Fat: 4.5 g | Saturated Fat: 0.5 g | Sodium: 610 mg | Total Carbohydrate: 50.5 g | Dietary Fiber: 9 g | Protein: 11.5 g 

For more recipes, please visit https://www.nutrition.va.gov

A majority of likely voters say they are more enthusiastic than usual about voting next November.

title: Exposing the Massive Fraud & Political Corruption in Minnesota and California
summary:
Exposing the Massive Fraud & Political Corruption in Minnesota and California

In this episode, we delve into the staggering fraud and corruption that has taken hold in Minnesota and California. We examine how dozens of individuals, predominantly from the East African and Somali communities, have been convicted of stealing over a billion dollars from taxpayer-funded programs during the COVID-19 pandemic. Governor Tim Walz's administration is under scrutiny for its failure to address this, allegedly due to fears of losing political support. We also explore similar issues in California, where illegal immigrants have fraudulently obtained commercial driver's licenses, leading to deadly accidents. This episode highlights the broader impacts of mass immigration and inadequate assimilation on the rule of law in the United States. 00:00 Massive COVID-19 Fraud in Minnesota 00:25 Governor's Response and Accountability 01:24 Political Implications and Media Coverage 02:13 Details of the Fraud Scandal 05:31 Broader Issues of Immigration and Multiculturalism 07:46 Specific Cases of Fraud and Corruption 19:50 Illegal Immigrants and Fraudulent Licenses 35:00 Conclusion and Final Thoughts

title: Welcoming the Montford Point Marine Association California
summary: The California State Commanders Veterans Council is proud to welcome the Montford Point Marine Association California as our newest member. Founded in 1965, the Montford Point Marine Association is dedicated to honoring and preserving the legacy of the first African American Marines who trained at Montford Point, Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, between 1942 and 1949. title: Protecting Veterans’ Benefits: Why California’s SB 694 Should Lead the Nation
summary: An Analytical Brief from CAL EANGUS Leadership A National Issue, A California Solution A recent Washington Post investigation has renewed scrutiny on the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) disability compensation system, alleging widespread overreach, fraud, and inefficiencies. The report described how outdated disability rules, a surge of minor and unverifiable claims, and a lack of enforcement capacity […]

title: California State Commanders Veterans Council Unites for Legislative Priorities in Visalia
summary: On October 18, 2025, the California State Commanders Veterans Council (CSCVC) convened its quarterly conference in Visalia, California, bringing together more than 20 representatives from Military and Veterans Service Organizations (MSOs and VSOs) from across the state. The CSCVC serves as a unified voice for California’s veterans community—advocating for legislation, benefits, and policies that improve […]

title: From Protection to Prosecution: The New Face of DOJ
summary:
Federal Government Focus: School Board Controversy & FBI Achievements

Do you remember the controversy over the federal government's intervention in school board meetings? This episode delves into the Department of Justice's priorities under Merrick Garland and the involvement of the National Security Division in parental disagreements at school boards. Additionally, we highlight the FBI's achievements in combating violent crime, seizing illegal firearms and drugs, and arresting top criminals during the Trump administration. Is this the best use of federal resources? Should local or state law enforcement handle such issues? Discover the contrasting focuses and effectiveness between administrations.

title: CADEM Ramps Up Voter Protection Efforts Ahead of November 2025 Election
summary:

title: Beyond Wokeness: A Call for True Leadership in Law Enforcement and Politics
summary:
Beyond Wokeness: A Call for True Leadership in Law Enforcement and Politics

With special guest Marc Gomez (Retired Sergeant CHP) we dive into the current state of leadership and its challenges. From the Attorney General candidate Jay Jones' scandal in Virginia to the controversial decision by Chicago PD's Chief of Patrol, we explore how politics influence critical decisions. We also examine Secretary of War Pete Hegseth's bold statements on restoring military standards and how this contrasts with the perceived lack of leadership in places like Chicago. How is leadership shaping the future of our institutions? Can we navigate through political influence to uphold professionalism and safety? Join the discussion and get the facts.

title: ABC7: California retired veterans and families to benefit from new military pension tax exemption
summary: REDLANDS, Calif. (KABC) — Veterans have served and sacrificed for our nation, and on Tuesday, the state of California announced a new law to help them in retirement. That law will exempt part of their military pensions from state income tax. At American Legion Post 106 in Redlands, Assemblymember James Ramos (D-San Bernardino) stood before retired […]
